caption:
Table 1: 
Quantitative comparison on DAVIS [6].
description: This table presents a quantitative comparison of different video generation methods on the DAVIS [6] dataset.  The metrics used for comparison include the Frechet Inception Distance (FID), which measures the quality of generated images; the Frechet Video Distance (FVD), which assesses the quality of generated videos; and the Object Motion Consistency (ObjMC), which evaluates how well the generated object motions match the predefined trajectories.  The comparison includes the results from three different methods: DragAnything [47], DragNUWA 1.5 [53], and the authors' proposed LeviTor model, both under settings with single and multiple control points. The results show that the LeviTor method outperforms other approaches in terms of FID and FVD, indicating superior image and video quality.

caption:
Table 2: 
Ablations on Object Instance and Depth information.
description: This table presents the results of ablation studies conducted to evaluate the impact of object instance and depth information on the performance of the LeviTor model.  The study removes either object instance information, depth information, or both, and assesses the resulting impact on FID, FVD, and ObjMC scores. This allows for a quantitative analysis of the contribution of these data elements to the model's accuracy and effectiveness in video generation.

caption:
Table S1: 
Quantitative comparison with Single-point Control on DAVIS [6].
description: Table S1 provides a quantitative comparison of video generation results between using single-point control and the proposed LeviTor method on the DAVIS dataset. The metrics used for comparison include FID (Fréchet Inception Distance) for image quality, FVD (Fréchet Video Distance) for video quality, and ObjMC (object motion consistency) for evaluating the accuracy of the generated motion. Lower scores for FID, FVD, and ObjMC indicate better quality and motion accuracy.
